meanings.definition: Cause to lose enthusiasm and initiative.
meanings.sent1: Too much criticism can stultify a person's motivation to try new things.
meanings.sent2: The monotonous tasks at work can stultify employees over time.
meanings.sent3: Trying to juggle too many tasks at once can stultify your energy and make you feel overwhelmed.
meanings.sent4: The oppressive heat seemed to stultify any desire to go outside and enjoy the day.
meanings.sent5: The constant negativity from his boss began to stultify his passion for his job.

meanings.definition: Cause to appear foolish or absurd.
meanings.sent1: His attempt to fix the broken vase only served to stultify the situation further.
meanings.sent2: The comedian's jokes sometimes stultify rather than entertain the audience.
meanings.sent3: Wearing mismatched socks might stultify your outfit, but it's a fun fashion statement.
meanings.sent4: The politician's contradictory statements stultify his credibility in the eyes of the public.
meanings.sent5: The magician's failed trick only managed to stultify his reputation for being skilled.

meanings.sent1: The exaggerated claims in the advertisement stultify the product's actual benefits.
meanings.sent2: Her extravagant spending habits stultify her financial stability.
meanings.sent3: Wearing a winter coat in the middle of summer would stultify your sense of appropriate dressing.
meanings.sent4: The teacher's sarcastic remarks sometimes stultify the seriousness of the lesson.
meanings.sent5: His constant bragging only serves to stultify his reputation among his peers.
